questions.question_text: A UTM is deployed on the external edge of the main corporate office. The office connects to the WAN port of the edge router. The edge router at the main office connects to the remote offices using GRE IPSec tunnels. A network administrator notices that a worm that was not detected by the UTM has spread from the remote sites into the corporate network. The UTM currently has traffic rules applied that should block the port used by the worm. Which of the following steps would MOST likely correct this issue?

discussion.content: Since worms have the ability to use a random port for transmission, then stateful packet inspection would be a great option for stopping them, as this may also block some traffic in case it shows any nefarious behaviour

From the network+ textbook the last paragraph states the follow - Leaving a default password on a firewall and permitting all traffic through the firewall from the outside untrusted network are two 
examples of a misconfigured firewall

No where in the entire section on UTM's does it state anything about the UTM being located on the edge or inside of the LAN. But it states a misconfigured firewall of the UTM could lead to vulnerabilities
I am going with C as the UTM is supposed to be outside of the LAN.

Selected Answer: C
Stateful packet insp. can detect the worm

Selected Answer: A
The answer is A. 
Current Infrastructure:
Remote Sites --> GRE/IPSecTunnels Endpoint Router -->Internet -->UTM -->GRE/IPSecEndpoint Router --> Main Site
UTM wont be able to inspect internal IP packet because it is encrypted (IPsec) and encapsulated(GRE) between the 2 site to site VPN endpoints. (Routers).

D. is not correct because the Site to Site VPN would cease to function.
B. is not correct because IPSec does not use TLS encryption.
C. is not correct because a firewall included in an UTM would be a Stateful Packet Inspection firewall by default. Don't ever recalling a feature setting that would enable or disable SPI in Checkpoint, Sophos, Fortinet UTMs. A router with a ACL is a Stateless FW, pretty much every modern firewall, especially a UTM would be using SPI.
i Used this questions and it really helped me in the exam and i passed last week...PBQs really helped....know the concept and you will be good

comments.content: so what's the answer? literally no one is agreeing here

discussion.content: I am a robot. I win!

Stateful-inspection firewalls: Unlike packet-filtering firewalls, stateful-inspection firewalls can track and “understand” when a TCP connection has occurred. This allows for reply traffic to be allowed through the firewall without the need for explicit rules. As a result, stateful-inspection firewalls make configuration easier, but can add a bit more inspection overhead and slow down traffic slightly more than packet-filtering firewalls. so C could be the correct answer
So ... is it C the correct answer?

comments.content: "UTM currently has traffic rules applied that should block the port used by the worm", the port being used by the worm. Worms replicate themselves without human intervention, stateful packet inspection would detect the worm regardless of what port it's using.

discussion.content: The correct answer is A. It says the utm can already block the worm
Stateful packet inspection can prevent worms.

choices.C: Enable stateful inspection on the UTM
choices.B: Enable TLS inspection on the UTM
choices.D: Configure the UTM to deny encrypted files from being transferred
choices.A: Move the UTM onto the LAN side of the network

questions.question_text: Which of the following would allow a device to maintain the same IP address lease based on the physical address of the network card?

discussion.content: That moment in a test when the Answer has been A for 4 questions in a row...

Selected Answer: A
Physical Address = MAC Address

Because it says the 'physical address' and physical address is another word for MAC address. Launch CMD in windows and type 'ipconfig/all' next to physical address you will find the MAC address of your device.

comments.content: I think it's because it's an IP lease, which indicates DHCP
static IP can be manually set so it isn't dependent on the device's physical address(MAC)

discussion.content: Why not B? Anyone?

choices.C: Replace users' network cables with known-good network cables
choices.A: Determine if any network equipment was replaced recently
choices.B: Verify malware has not disabled the users' PC firewalls

questions.question_text: Users are reporting their network is extremely slow. The technician discovers pings to external host have excessive response times. However, internal pings to printers and other PCs have acceptable response times. Which of the following steps should the technician take NEXT?

discussion.content: I initially choose D also BUT the troubleshooting process says to determine if any changes have been made to the network therefore A is the better answer.

i just think back to the OSI model in regards to this question. but i can see how this would throw someone off you can cross off C because we already know they are able to ping everything fine but to the external host its slow but still connects. D has nothing to do with anything. it is very easy to answer B but considering that we know nothing about the overall equipment the safest answer would be a bottom up approach to this question

comments.content: You must determine any changes before making a drastic decision, if this production network is for a big company then we cant afford to just shut down the server. We must first attempt to find the cause before jumping to conclusions as this could result in unnecessary down time and a loss of finances!

discussion.content: Could anyone shed some light why the correct answer is not D?

hexadecimal is known as base-16, hex alone is base-6.

The question is formatted wrong.

comments.content:
base - 6 is senary
Hexadecimal / hex is interchangeable.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a system of notation that uses base 16 rather than base 10?

A network administrator would like to collect information from several networking devices using SNMP. Which of the following SNMP options should a network administrator use to ensure the data transferred is confidential?

discussion.content:
AuthPriv is the most correct answer. SNMPv3 defines communication with authentication and privacy (AuthPriv) as one of three mechanisms available. It uses MD5 and SHA for authentication and either DES or AES for privacy.
While both SHA and MD5 are used in the solution, they are insufficient on their own.
A passphrase would be insufficient to sustain confidentiality of the data.

comments.content: Did you google Authpriv or did you come across the term from studying CompTIA's Network + objectives?
It is not in the objectives. Takoyaki does a lot of copy and pasting which means they are all searches from the interwebs.

If you know SNMP, you know authpriv, I chose this answer after reading the question and eliminating the other choices. CompTIA isn't going to care about your objective comments when you sit down to take the Network+.

discussion.content: page 394 of the official Comptia net+ prayer guide and songbook, Authpriv is defined as offering HMAC MD5 or SHA authentication and provides privacy through encryption.

The authPriv level requires that the user connect with the SNMP username, and requires that it has been signed with the Auth password and that it has been encrypted with the Priv password.

So A is a combination of B, C, D which means it's the most wholistic answer
I’m glad authpriv came up here. If it didn’t, I’d see it for the first time on the exam. I’m amazed at how much I’ve never heard of, even after working, going to class, and studying so much.
Also first time coming across Authpriv. Not in the objectives, not in the course notes. Yikesss!
Thanks Takoyaki for that useful insight
